The Cabrach is a remote and sparsely populated area on the northern edge of the Cairngorms National Park, in Moray, North East Scotland. An area of particular natural beauty it was once a self-sustaining upland settlement but has since suffered depopulation over the last century which threatens the loss of the heritage and history of this unique area. The Cabrach Trust was established in 2011 with a vision to regenerate the Cabrach as a thriving and sustainable

Component 1: Heritage Interpretation Centre and Visitor Centre
£75,000 project costs
The development of a new Heritage Interpretation Centre to provide a meeting place for the community and visitors, to pay tribute to the Cabrach's fascinating past, to provide a range of facilities and to be an educational resource.
Project Duration:
December 2016 - May 2017
This project seeks to generate income through interpretation, community events and craft camps
Construction of a Visitor Centre on the Trust

Highland Council have provided additional funding of £300,000 towards the project which will enable the development of the Eco Cabrach Visitor Centre at the Visitor Centre on the Cabrach Trust's site at Meall Mòr above the village of Kinbuck. When completed the Visitor Centre will tell the story of the local wildlife, wildlife reserves and nature reserves, the farming and forestry in the area and the local settlement, whilst offering stunning views towards the Cairngorms.

The turbine will have a maximum tip height of 80m. The total hub height will be between 20m and 22.5m. The maximum blade tip height above the nearest point of the Sundial will be 63m.

The Trust successfully applied to the Heritage Lottery Fund (HLF) for a Lottery Programme Grant to create a community led regeneration strategy for the Cabrach which included the development of a Case for Change for the area. Once completed, the Trust planned to apply for HLF funding for the regeneration strategy. Following this the Trust would have completed a project to restore and convert two ancient farm steadings into a museum and hub, and the restoration of the Community Hall and an extension to house the new

The Cabrach Trust is currently working with SITA Trust to develop a community led regeneration plan also known as a Community Asset Transfer Plan. A Community Asset Transfer Plan will set out how the Cabrach Trust's land and assets will be developed and how new skills will be learned and training will be provided for local people.

Example 2: The Tayport Photographic Archive is an online archive of photographs, oral history recordings and memorabilia capturing the history and heritage of the Fife town of Tayport between the two World Wars. The archive has taken two years to collect, catalog and publish local community resources from a time when Tayport was a thriving port and social centre for local communities. The Cabrach Trust is an organisation with a clear vision to regenerate the Cabrach, a rural community just north of the Cairngorms National Park, as a thriving and sustainable community, celebrating the landscape and it's heritage. By developing a community led regeneration strategy we have already seen the creation of jobs and have seen visitors returning to the area to see local rural crafts and way of life. To achieve these goals, The Cabrach Trust has developed a community led regeneration strategy that

The Cabrach Trust is a registered charitable trust, established in 2011 to regenerate the Cabrach area in new ways. It aims to improve the quality of life and opportunities in the Cabrach, raise the profile of the area and encourage other development.

The Cabrach is a community organisation that seeks to revitalise and re-energise the local economy through the creation of social enterprise projects to provide employment and opportunities for local involvement. By promoting collaboration and entrepreneurship, with communities

in the local area. There is the potential to expand other business activities, such as craft beer brewing and local whisky tourism.

The land surrounding the Distillery has been marked out to become a working distillery with a tourist centre and aims to help revive the area and bring work back to the area. The site also retains its ancient function as a mill site and numerous archaeological site features are visible in the field. A mini hydro scheme was installed by the Shetland Islands Charitable Trust in

. The plans include the restoration of the original buildings and the addition of the shop and exhibition space.

The distillery is located at the foot of Gelderlochan, near the village of Inverey. The Cabrach area is a fertile mix of pasture and crop farming land and the local community hope that the distillery will assist in the development of ‘value added farming’ opportunities, nurturing the existing farming community whilst promoting the local produce that this area has to offer.

for local people and of course, bring more visitors to the area.

"One of the reasons for establishing the Distillery was to provide new employment opportunities in this part of the country. A Community-Owned Distillery is an excellent way for smaller communities like ours to flourish and The Cabrach Distillery will help ensure the survival of this beautiful area. The benefits of having a distillery on the site include the creation of new jobs, bringing much needed increase in tourism and reviving

The farm has a large planting area and is aiming to integrate a children's play area and forest school into the woodland.

to rejuvenate the farm and diversify its income. A broadleaf native woodland has grown to over 100 acres. Forest Garden products are now sold at local farmers markets and other local outlets. The aim of Wantonwells is to create a forest garden that is commercially viable, providing income to the farm, growing high quality food to be sold in local shops and a source of employment.

to provide timber to produce fine furniture. The woodland is managed specifically for the growth of high quality native broadleaf trees and the land has been depleted of all conifer trees. Wantonwells has a mix of native broadleaf tree species of ash, hazel, field maple, silver birch, common alder and rowan, providing a natural habitat for a wealth of wildlife. as a means of diversifying the farm and creating new revenue to reinvest in the local community and environment. Wantonwells Wood is now a successful and well-established nursery, managed to a high standard, with trees stocked at a sustainable level and grown for the production of quality native broadleaf woodland seedlings. project is to have a natural system of woodland, managing and growing our native, broadleaf trees back into their natural habitat and providing the space for wildlife to flourish. With benefits to the environment, biodiversity, local communities and heritage, the woodland is a commercial venture, providing opportunities and involvement for local schools, environmental management and conservation.

with a vision to restore a dynamic, utilising landscape to provide a natural habitat for both native and commercially important broadleaf tree species. Funded by multiple organisations and agencies, the regeneration project has reintroduced native tree species to the site, with hundreds of oak trees planted in consecutive years and a large area of woodland established. The success of the plantation has also seen the planting of native broadleaf species and softwood forestry, with young forestry trees introduced to the site.

Example 2: A family owned farm of over 100 acres in the heart of the north east of Scotland, Wantonwells, started planting woodland in 1993,

Involving local schools and communities and providing education, training and employment opportunities, the regeneration has created a popular, beautiful farm that is now a destination for the local and wider community. Future plans include

In conjunction with the woodlands, a market garden is being developed along the woodland edge to provide fresh vegetables, salads and other foodstuffs to the local community, further afield and for sale to local shops. The planned development of a Visitor Centre will showcase the work that is being carried out by the Trust, with the addition of a cafe and children's play area.
Example 2: Wantonwells Farm is a community woodland and market garden, a beautifully rural and diverse traditional Aber

A number of the young trees are harvested for use as firewood, and for use in the house.
The focus of the garden is the production of high quality vegetables, fruit, flowers and herbs. Today Wantonwells Farm is home not just to the original fruit orchard planted in 1990, but also has many other gardens and planted areas including several varieties of native broadleaf trees, with the aim of creating a more diverse and productive native woodland, which will act as a habitat for native

The woodland provides a variety of different species, ages and conditions to adapt to different uses throughout the year. The woodland is stocked with native broadleaf trees, as well as an array of undergrowth species such as hazel, rowan, holly, aspen, birch, cherry and elderflower. This incorporates a variety of locally sourced medicinal plants, fruits and berries to sustain the woodland's yield. An area of land has also been planted with a crop of 100 acres of broadleaf native
A unique concept for rural Aberdeenshire, a forest garden has been created where trees are grown from seed to a saleable size and managed for natural growth.

Wantonwels has been converted into a small scale, successful and positively growing project over the last 14 years. The range of products now sold from the site has grown beyond the initial nursery and cut flowers to include cider making, forage crops for pigs, eggs and poultry. Many of the surrounding fields are now planted with native broadleaf trees, providing a beautiful woodland area for the local community and wildlife. A children's play area has been developed from dusty unused fields, with well painted play equipment

Companies that have been created on the farm include The White Tree, a garden of native broadleaf trees and Woodland Workshop, a woodland nursery and teaching garden. In 2007, The Wantonwells Trust was formed by the owners of the farm to oversee the development of the projects on the site, with a vision to eventually create a community woodland, forest garden and market garden, selling directly to the public. The Trust's vision for this development is to create a place for everyone in the community to

Much of the native woodland was destroyed when the Grampian Expressway was built, and so it became the mission of the new owners to replant, creating a woodland that was lacking and degraded. In the past 20 years, hundreds of native, broadleaf trees have been planted with their bare root systems shrouded in straw to protect them through their first winter in the ground. Since then a natural woodland, rich in wildlife, has begun to mature and wildlife such as roe deer have started to use

A traditional mixed livestock and arable farm, in the heartland of the north east of Scotland, Wantonwells was purchased in 1990, with a vision to regenerate the farm to provide a profitable market garden and woodland.

for locals to become involved in the setting up and running of the business. The project has been undertaken as a social enterprise with the aim of reinvesting surplus income into the community of The Cabrach. A new Heritage Centre is set to be built attached to the Distillery and will celebrate and display the history of The Cabrach, whilst providing further awareness about the cultural and environmental history of the area.

Example 1:

The original distillery, set in a beautiful location on the banks of the Cabrach Burn, had fallen into disuse around 1820 and was used as a farm store. In 2007, the Trust was approved to purchase the distillery and land, with the aim of restoring the original distillery to a working condition. In addition to bringing this historic building back into use, The Cabrach Distillery hopes that it will become a landmark building in the local community and will create employment opportunities

Details: The Cabrach, rural community, Cairngorms National Park, community project, social enterprise, rural regeneration, jobs, heritage, history, sustainable community, distillery, started 2011
Example 1: The Cabrach is a remote and sparsely populated area on the northern edge of the Cairngorms National Park, in Moray, North East Scotland. An area of particular natural beauty it was once a self-sustaining upland settlement but has since suffered depopulation over the last century which threatens the loss of the heritage and history of this unique area. The Cabrach Trust was established in 2011 with a vision to regenerate the Cabrach as a thriving and sustainable community, creating jobs, attracting visitors whilst protecting and celebrating the history, landscape and heritage for future generations. To achieve these goals The Cabrach Trust has developed a community led regeneration strategy that will see the development of projects such as a historic Distillery and a new Heritage Centre on the Trust's land.
